intro: Rosa tomentosa f. multiglandulosa, commonly known as the hairy rose or woolly rose, is a botanical variant of the species Rosa tomentosa. It is characterized by its dense, white to grayish pubescence covering the stems, leaves, and flowers. The leaves are pinnately compound, typically consisting of 5–9 elliptical leaflets with serrated margins. Its flowers are usually pink to red, with a prominent central pistil and numerous stamens. This form is valued in horticulture for its ornamental appearance and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
